The effect of textural properties of CeO2-SiO2 mixed oxides on NH3-SCO activity of Pt/CeO2-SiO2 catalyst Shiying Chang a b Gavin Harle b Jiangli Ma b Jianhong Yi a * a Kunming University of Science and Technology, Faculty of Material Science and Engineering, Kunming, China Kunming University of Science and Technology Faculty of Material Science and Engineering Kunming China Kunming University of Science and Technology, Faculty of Material Science and Engineering, Kunming, China b Kunming Sino-Platinum Metals Catalyst Co, Ltd, Kunming, China Kunming Sino-Platinum Metals Catalyst Co, Ltd Kunming China Kunming Sino-Platinum Metals Catalyst Co, Ltd, Kunming, China) ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of CeO2-SiO2 (CS) mixed oxides with different textural properties were prepared by sol-gel methodology using different synthesis temperatures (STemps) in order to investigate the influence of the CS mixed oxide support on the NH3-SCO activity for Pt/CS catalysts. The results showed that the support material had a significant effect on catalytic activity. A Pt/CS catalyst, CS material synthesized at 40 °C (CS40) with a core-shell structure, high dispersion and good CeO2 crystallinity, showed excellent NH3 oxidation activity at low temperatures which was superior to the traditional Pt/Al2O3 tested. Characterization results showed that highly dispersed CeO2 on SiO2 with good CeO2 crystallinity was favorable towards the formation of surface /lattice oxygen and medium strong acid both of which were important for the NH3 oxidation reaction. This work suggests that the Pt/CS40 catalyst is a more suitable alternative to traditional lower layer Pt/Al2O3 catalyst for dual ammonia slip catalyst (ASC). Keywords CeO2-SiO2 NH3-SCO Pt/CeO2-SiO2 Pt/Al2O3 Dual ammonia slip catalyst 1 Introduction With the implementation of increasingly stringent vehicle emission regulations, there are considerable challenges in achieving the required low-temperature catalytic performance within vehicular emissions control systems. In order to meet the requirements of ultra-low NOx emissions, the urea SCR system has become an essential component of heavy-duty diesel vehicles. However for urea based SCR systems, NH3 slip can be caused by a number of factors including excessive injection of urea solution, crystallization of urea and high relative temperatures [1]. NH3 slip is undesired due to the resulting difficulties in meeting emission limits required within the latest regulations (<10 ppm for China Stage-6 emissions legislation). NH3 is also a toxic inorganic gas and represents an important atmospheric ammonium ion (NH4 +) source capable of forming secondary aerosols, thus posing a significant threat to human health. Selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 to N2 (NH3-SCO) is the favored method for the removal of NH3 (reaction 1). However this reaction can also result in the formation of the undesired by-products N2O, NO and NO2 according to reactions 2–4. (1) 4NH3 + 3O2 → 2N2 + 6H2O (2) 2NH3 + 2O2 → N2O + 3H2O (3) 4NH3 + 5O2 → 4NO + 6H2O (4) 4NH3 + 7O2 → 4NO2 + 6H2O As a result of the requirement to reduce NH3 slip, ammonia slip catalysts (ASCs) have become a key component of after-treatment catalyst systems for diesel vehicles, with traditional Pt/Al2O3 catalysts demonstrating high NH3 oxidation activity above 250 ℃ [1,2]. However their application does also result in the formation of a significant number of undesired byproducts such as N2O and NOx leading to increases in total NOx emissions [2–5]. In order to resolve this issue, dual-layer ASC products have been developed consisting of both an upper layer SCR catalyst component and a lower layer PGM catalyst component to increase the selectivity of the NH3 oxidation process towards N2 [6–8]. Within such dual-layer ASCs NH3 first encounters the upper SCR layer where some of the NH3 is stored on the SCR catalyst while the remaining NH3 diffuses to the lower PGM layer where it is oxidized by O2 to form N2, N2O, and NOx. Upon diffusion back through the upper SCR layer NOx reacts with stored and additional NH3 forming N2 and N2O. This has been shown to be an effective method to decrease the yield of NOx by-products. However it has been demonstrated that exhaust temperatures within a diesel vehicle may be as low as 180−250 ℃ [9]. As such there remains a risk of NH3 slip at temperatures below 250 ℃ within current ASC designs. Improving the NH3 oxidation activity at low temperature has therefore become a significant challenge for dual layer ASC development, with focus on the lower layer PGM catalyst component due to its functionality in the NH3 oxidation process. It is well known that the support material is a vital factor affecting the activity of catalysts. Qu and co-workers investigated the effect of four different supports (NaY, SiO2, Al2O3 and TiO2) on NH3-SCO performance and found that the support played an important role in the formation of different Ag species, the distribution of Ag° species, and NH3 activation due to acid sites [10]. Kim and co-workers have studied the influence of support material on the low temperature activity of Pt/Fe based catalysts [11] and their results demonstrated that the structure and activity of the final catalysts were largely influenced by the choice of support material. Pt was found to be highly dispersed exclusively on Fe oxide when using ZSM5 as a support and as such ZSM5 was identified as a more suitable support for Pt/FeOx species in terms of catalyzing NH3 oxidation than Al2O3 and SiO2. In addition Qi and co-workers assessed a series of Fe exchanged zeolite catalysts (FER, MOR, Y, Beta and ZSM5) for their activity towards NH3-SCO, with Fe/ZSM5 identified as the most active catalyst [12]. It is therefore apparent that a suitable support material represents an important factor in improving and optimizing the NH3-SCO performance of ASC catalysts. Cerium-based oxide materials have been shown to be an ideal support material for catalysts for the NH3-SCO reaction due to their excellent redox properties [13–16]and as such have been identified as the focus for this work. Zhang and co-workers reported that incorporation of Cu onto Ce-Zr mixed oxides can further improve NH3 oxidation activity and that Cu-Ce-Zr mixed oxides prepared by a citric acid sol-gel methodology can achieve complete NH3 oxidation conversion at 230 ℃ [13]. Wang and co-workers have shown that Ce-Zr mixed oxides can achieve complete NH3 oxidation conversion at approximately 360 ℃ [14]. In addition, Chen and co-workers have demonstrated that addition of IrO2 to Ce0.6Zr0.4O2 can facilitate NH3 oxidation at lower temperatures [15]. However, sintering of cerium is known to occur at high temperature resulting in a deterioration in redox properties [16,17]. As a result of this, the thermal stability of ceriumusually need to be improved by the addition of selected oxides so as to form stable composite oxides or solid solutions [13–15]. SiO2 has the advantages of good thermal stability, high surface area and sulfur tolerance and has been shown to be an ideal support material [18,19]. CeO2-SiO2 mixed oxides with good sulfur tolerance and high surface area can be obtained by the combination of CeO2 and SiO2, which is an excellent support material for catalysts [20,21]. In this work we have prepared a number of CeO2-SiO2 (CS) mixed oxide materials to investigate their application as support materials within Pt-based catalysts for the selective catalytic oxidation of NH3. The majority of current research related to support materials examines their influence on the dispersion, valence state and size of active metals as well as final catalytic activity, with few studies in the literature focusing on the relationship between support material properties and activity. As such this paper focuses on the physicochemical properties of the prepared CS mixed oxide supports and their final catalytic activity, in order to provide suggestions for the selection and preparation of support materials. The NH3-SCO performance of the Pt/CS catalysts prepared were studied using a fixed-bed micro reactor to assess the functionality of CS mixed oxides in comparison to the Al2O3 of a more conventional Pt/Al2O3 ASC. In addition the relationship between the structural properties of CS mixed oxides and activity was investigated using N2 adsorption, XRD, TEM, HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and O2-TPD techniques. A Ce/Si molar ratio of 1 was chosen for this work based upon our previous studies of CS mixed oxides as support materials [20]. 2 Experimental 2.1 CS mixed oxides preparation CS (Ce/Si = 1) mixed oxides were prepared using the sol-gel method. Appropriate amounts of TEOS (44 mL) and C2H5OH (200 mL) were mixed together and stirred for 10 min. The solution was then added to a mixture of C2H5OH (400 mL), H2O (19 mL) and NH3⸱H2O (33 mL) and stirred for 6 h at different temperatures, STemps, resulting in the formation of SiO2. Finally, a solution of Ce (NO3)3.6H2O (30 g) in C2H5OH (50 mL) was added using a peristaltic pump and the mixture stirred continuously for 2 h at the same STemp. The resulting precipitates were then separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol, and dried at 110 ℃ for 12 h. The powders were then calcined at 450 ℃ in a muffle furnace for 4 h. The preparation method was repeated to obtain a series of CS mixed oxides prepared using different STemps with CS30, CS40, CS50, and CS60 corresponding to STemps of 30 ℃, 40 ℃, 50 ℃, and 60 ℃ respectively. Pt/CS and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts containing 1 wt% Pt were prepared via aqueous impregnation. 99 g of CS mixed oxide or Al2O3 was dispersed in deionized water at room temperature with continuous stirring for 30 min, followed by the addition of 100 g of (HOCH2CH2NH3)2[Pt (OH) 6] solution (1 wt% Pt). Following homogenization for 1 h at room temperature, the slurry was dried at 110 ℃ for 12 h. The dried powders were then calcined at 550 ℃ in a muffle furnace for 1 h. The resulting Pt/CS30, Pt/CS40, Pt/CS50, and Pt/CS60 catalysts obtained correspond to the differing support oxides CS30, CS40, CS50, and CS60. 2.2 Material characterization Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume measurements were obtained from N2 adsorption isotherms using a Quantachrome NovaWin2 sorption analyzer. Powder samples were pretreated at 150 ℃ for 15 min in a vacuum prior to adsorption testing. BET and pore volume were calculated by the DFT method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were used to determine the structure of the samples on a Philips X’pert Pro diffractometer with a Ni filter and Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.15418 nm) and operated at 40kv and 100 mA. The diffraction data was obtained at a scanning rate of 10 ℃/min between 10° to 90° 2θ. The morphology of the CS mixed oxide samples was observed via high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) on a TECNAI F-30 high resolution transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. . X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to determine the chemical species on the surface of the CS mixed oxide samples at 15 kV and 50 W using a Physical Electronics PHI 5500 spectrometer. The multi-peak-resolution analysis of XPS patterns was carried out by using Origin software. H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were performed on a Quantachrome CHEMBET 3000 chemisorption instrument using an H2-Ar gas mixture (10% of H2 by volume) as the reductant. 100 mg of sample was first pretreated in an Ar gas stream at 350 °C for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature under an H2-Ar gas stream, before finally switching to a He-Ar gas mixture with a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. Temperature programmed experiments were then carried out over a temperature range of RT to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. H2 consumption was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and multi-peak-resolution analysis of H2-TPR curves was carried out using Origin software. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out on a Quantachrome CHEMBET 3000 chemisorption instrument. 100 mg of powder sample was placed in a quartz U-tube reactor and pretreated at 400 °C in a He gas stream with a total flow of 45 mL/min for 1 h. Following cooling to room temperature the sample was treated with NH3 with a total flow of 45 mL/min at 50 °C for 1 h. The sample was then flushed with He at 50 mL/min for 1 h, and NH3-TPD experiments were performed in a He gas stream from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. Multi-peak resolution analysis of NH3-TPD profiles was carried out using Origin software. O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) experiments were carried out on a Quantachrome CHEMBET 3000 chemisorption instrument. 100 mg of powder sample was placed in a quartz U-tube reactor and pretreated at 400 °C in a synthetic air gas stream with a total flow rate of 50 mL/min for 1 h before cooling to room temperature. The sample was then treated with O2 (50 mL/min) for 1 h at 50 °C, and flushed with He (50 mL/min) for 1 h. O2-TPD experiments were then performed from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. Multi-peak resolution analysis of O2-TPD profiles was carried out using Origin software. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests 2.3.1 NH3-SCO tests NH3-SCO activity testing was performed using a fixed-bed micro reactor. 0.34 g of powder catalyst samples with an average diameter of 40–60 mesh were placed in a stainless steel tube with an inner diameter of 5 mm. The catalyst samples were pretreated at 150 ℃ in N2 for 10 min prior to activity testing and then cooled to 170 ℃. A reaction gas mixture consisting of 200 ppm NH3, and 10% O2 in N2 stream was then introduced at a flow rate of 2.31 L/min (space velocity (Sv) of 407 L g-1 h-1). The reaction was studied between a temperature range of 170 ℃ to 450 ℃. Outlet gas concentrations of NH3, NO, NO2 and N2O were analyzed at steady state using an MKS analyzer. NH3 oxidation conversion was calculated using Eq. (1) where C(NH3-out) and C(NH3-in) represent the outlet and inlet concentration of NH3 respectively. (1) C o n N H 3 = C ( N H 3 - I n ) - C ( N H 3 - O u t ) C ( N H 3 - I n ) * 100 % N2 selectivity was calculated using Eq. (2) where C(NO), C(NO2) and C(N2O) represent the outlet concentration of NO, NO2 and N2O, respectively (2) S N 2 = 1 - C ( N O ) + C ( N O 2 ) + 2 * ( N 2 O ) C ( N H 3 - I n ) - C ( N H 3 - O u t ) * 100 % 2.3.2 NO oxidation tests NO oxidation activity testing was performed using a fixed-bed micro reactor. 1 g powder catalyst samples with an average diameter of 40–60 mesh were placed in a stainless steel tube with an inner diameter of 5 mm. The catalyst samples were pretreated at 100 ℃ in N2 for 10 min followed by heating to 500 ℃ in a gas mixture of 400 ppm NO/N2, and cooling to 100 ℃ prior to activity testing. A reaction mixture gas consisting of 400 ppm NO, and 10% O2 in N2 was then introduced at a flow rate of 500 mL/min (space velocity (Sv) of 3 L g-1 h-1) and the temperature increased from 100 to 500 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. Outlet gas concentrations were measured online using MKS equipment. NO2/NOx ratios were calculated by Eq. (3) N O 2 / N O x = C ( N O 2 - O u t ) C ( N O - O u t ) + C ( N O 2 - O u t ) * 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCO performance 3.1.1 NH3 oxidation conversion The catalytic performance towards NH3-SCO for the Pt/CS catalyst samples is shown in Fig. 1 . It can be observed that all the catalysts showed complete NH3 conversion above 300 ℃, but that the low-temperature performance of the catalysts significantly differed in the range of 170−300 ℃. The Pt/CS40 catalyst sample showed the highest NH3 oxidation activity with an NH3 conversion of 84.26% at 200 ℃ whilst the NH3 conversion of the other catalyst samples was observed to be less than 10% at 200 ℃. NH3 conversions of the Pt/CS catalyst samples was observed to decrease in the order of Pt/CS40 > Pt/CS30 > Pt/CS60 > Pt/CS50 indicating that the STemp of the mixed oxide has a significant effect on the final catalytic properties. Fig. 1 also shows that the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst sample exhibits a similar NH3 oxidation performance to the Pt/CS60 catalyst sample with complete NH3 oxidation achieved at 250 ℃ but a significantly worse activity than the Pt/CS40 and Pt/CS30 samples. Indeed the NH3 conversion over the Pt/CS40 sample was increased by 76.05% in comparison to the Pt/Al2O3 sample at 200 ℃. These results suggest that an appropriately prepared CS mixed oxide represents a more suitable support than Al2O3 for Pt-based catalysts in terms of NH3 oxidation activity, particularly with regard to improved low temperature activity. 3.1.2 Formation of by-products and N2 selectivity Fig. 2 shows the concentration of by-products formed during the NH3-SCO reaction. It can be observed that for all catalyst samples tested the desired oxidation of NH3 to N2 was also accompanied by formation of NO, NO2 and N2O. Fig. 2 shows that N2O was the main by-product within a temperature range of 200−400 ℃ and that onset of formation of NOx by-products occurs at temperatures of greater than 250 ℃. These observations suggest that the NH3 oxidation pathway is closely related to reaction temperature. At temperatures lower than 250 ℃, NH3 was mainly oxidized to N2O and N2. However between a temperature range of 250−400 ℃, the N2O selectivity is observed to decrease and the NOx selectivity is increased. At temperatures greater than 400 ℃, N2O selectivity decreases to zero and NH3 is mainly oxidized to NO, NO2 and N2. From Fig. 2 (a), it can be observed that the concentration of the N2O by-product formed decreased in the following order: Pt/CS40 > Pt/CS30 > Pt/CS60 > Pt/Al2O3>Pt/CS50. This was consistent with the NH3 oxidation activity of catalysts and indicates that the higher the NH3 oxidation activity of Pt based catalysts, the higher the amount of N2O by-product formed. It can be seen in Fig. 2(b) that the same trend was seen for formation of NO2. However in Fig. 2 (c) it can be observed that the concentration of NO formed decreases in the order of Pt/CS50 > Pt/CS60 > Pt/CS30 > Pt/Al2O3>Pt/CS40, for the most part opposite to the oxidation activity of the catalyst samples. The reason for this is the potential for further oxidation of NO to NO2 over Pt based catalysts. Fig. 3 shows the NO oxidation activity over the Pt/CS catalyst samples. It can be observed that all Pt/CS catalyst samples display high NO oxidation performance. The highest NO oxidation conversion of Pt/CS was achieved at about 300 ℃ due to the NO oxidation reaction being affected by thermodynamics above 300 ℃ [22]. The Pt/CS60 and Pt/CS40 catalyst samples showed better NO oxidation performance than the other samples tested with the Pt/CS60 sample exhibiting the best light-off performance of 121 ℃ for NO conversion of 30% and the Pt/CS40 sample showing a maximum NO conversion of 90% at 300 ℃. The Pt/CS40 catalyst sample showed the highest activity towards NO oxidation resulting in increased levels of NO2 formed and decreased NO. The Pt/CS60 also showed high NO oxidation conversion and high levels of NO2 formation. It can therefore be inferred that the Pt/CS60 catalyst had a higher NO selectivity and produced significantly more NO2. Reduced NO2 and N2O and higher NO levels were detected for the Pt/CS50 catalyst due to its poor relative oxidation functionality. Fig. 4 shows the N2 selectivity of the Pt based catalyst samples. N2 selectivity was observed to decrease with increased temperature as a result of preferential conversion of NH3 to NO and NO2 at high temperature. The N2 selectivity of all the Pt based catalyst samples tested was observed to be less than 50% at temperatures of above 350 ℃. The Pt/CS40, Pt/CS30 and Pt/Al2O3 catalyst samples all showed higher than expected relative decreases in N2 selectivity between temperatures of 200 ℃ and 300 ℃in comparison to the relatively linear decrease in N2 selectivity with increased temperature that was observed for the Pt/CS50 and Pt/CS60 samples. The reason for this was their relative selectivity towards N2O within this temperature range. At temperatures of above 350 ℃, N2 selectivity was mainly influenced by NOx formation, which increased in a linear manner with temperature. The Pt/CS50 catalyst sample showed the highest N2 selectivity again due to its poor relative oxidation activity. The Pt/CS60 sample showed the lowest N2 selectivity due to the formation of large amount of N2O and NOx by-products. It can be seen from the above results that the support material has a significant effect on the NH3 oxidation activity for the Pt-based catalysts tested. For the CS mixed oxide samples, the CS40 sample, prepared at 40 ℃, showed a good low temperature NH3 oxidation performance (84% conversion at 200 ℃). The NH3 oxidation activity of the Pt/CS40 catalyst represented an obvious improvement over the Al2O3 supported catalyst, with the average NH3 oxidation conversion between 185−250 ℃ increased from 58.65%–83.42%, as shown in Fig. 5 . The N2 selectivity of the Pt/CS40 catalyst was lower than that of the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, and showed formation of high levels of NO2 and low NO. However it is important to consider that the fomation of NO2 in the PGM component of dual-layer ASCs is an important factor and has been shown to increase the conversion of NO and NH3 in the upper layer due to the fast SCR reaction [23]· As such these results suggest that the CS40 mixed oxide represents a potentially more suitable support material than Al2O3 for application with Pt-based catalysts within the lower PGM layer of dual-layer ASCs. 3.2 CS mixed oxides characterization 3.2.1 Surface area and pore structure of CS mixed oxides BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter data are summarized in Table 1 . The CS mixed oxides prepared, in general, displayed a high specific surface area with the surface area observed to significantly increase with increased STemp. It is often hypothesized that supports with relatively high surface areas contribute to increased noble metal dispersion and thus promote catalytic activity [24,25]. However the activity results obtained for the Pt/CS catalyst samples tested indicate that the surface area of the CS mixed oxides does not play a significant role in catalyst activity in this case. Average pore diameter and total pore volume measurements showed no clear trend with STemp. Table 1 shows that the average pore diameters of all samples were within a range of 2−7 nm. The CS40 mixed oxide sample exhibited the smallest average pore diameter, 2.1 nm, but with a total pore volume of 0.78 cm3/g. This total pore volume value was the highest of the samples tested, with the exception of CS60, indicating a potential abundance of micropores in the CS40 sample which could be favorable for the diffusion of reaction gases. 3.2.2 Phase structure of CS mixed oxides Fig. 6 shows the XRD patterns obtained for the prepared CS mixed oxides. The diffractograms show a typical diffraction pattern for CeO2 with characteristic peaks at 2θ = 28.554°, 33.084°, 47.487°, 56.347°, and 76.707°,corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (400), and (311) planes respectively ((JCPDS 34−0394). CeO2 has a cubic fluorite structure. The intensity of the diffraction peaks associated with CeO2 was observed to decrease with increasing STemp. A broad feature between 15 to 35° (2θ) associated with the amorphous structure of SiO2 was observed for the CS60 mixed oxide sample [26]. The XRD data obtained indicates that the crystallinity of CeO2 decreases with increasing STemp, which was subsequently confirmed by HRTEM analysis. Previous reports in the literature have shown that a solid solution is formed between CeO2 and SiO2 [27]. However there was no evidence observed within the XRD data obtained for formation of solid solutions between CeO2 and SiO2 in this case. The co-existence of CeO2 and SiO2 was not determined via XRD. Therefore, further analysis via TEM and HRTEM was conducted to confirm the morphology and structure of the CS mixed oxides. 3.2.3 Morphology and structure of CS mixed oxides The TEM images of the CS30, CS40, CS50 and CS60 samples are shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7 (a) shows that the CS30 sample was a mixture of both uniform microspheres with an average diameter of 45–60 nm as well as irregular clusters. To determine the composition of the microspheres and clusters, the image (Fig. 7 (a)) was magnified by 80,000 times with the results shown in Fig. 8 and 9 . Fig. 8 shows HRTEM images of a microsphere, and the lattice of CeO2 (111) plane can be clearly observed. No evidence was observed for the presence of SiO2 lattice due to amorphous structure of SiO2, which is in agreement with the XRD results obtained. In Fig. 8, CeO2 particles with a size of 2–3 nm were seen to be highly dispersed over amorphous SiO2 particles, confirming that the microspheres consisted of typical SiO2@CeO2 core-shell structure nanoparticles. Fig. 9 shows the HRTEM images of a cluster. It can be observed that the clusters consisted of aggregates of numerous fine CeO2 particles with diameters of 2–3 nm. The observations indicate that Ce exists in the form of CeO2 in the prepared CS mixed oxides samples and namely in two different states: CeO2 dispersed on SiO2 surface (CeO2-d) and CeO2 aggregates (CeO2-a). Fig. 7(b–d) demonstrates that the morphologies of CS40, CS50 and CS60 mixed oxide samples change significantly with increased STemp. The average diameter of the SiO2@CeO2 microspheres is observed to decrease and the observed number of CeO2-a decrease with increasing STemp. Fig. 10 (b–c) shows the grain state of CeO2 in the CS mixed oxides samples. From the images it can be observed that with an increase in STemp, the crystallinity of CeO2 appears to worsen and when STemp reaches 50 ℃ CeO2 crystallinity is obviously decreased. When STemp reaches 60 ℃, no evidence for CeO2 lattice was observed with the structure appearing amorphous. The results demonstrate that an STemp of greater than 50 °C is unfavorable for the crystallinity of CeO2.These findings again are in agreement with XRD. These observations are believed to be closely related to the preparation method for the CS mixed oxides. The synthetic route utilized for preparation of the CS mixed oxides samples is outlined in Fig. 11 . As previously discussed in the experimental section of this paper the first step of the preparation involved a hydrolysis–condensation reaction of TEOS. The formation of SiO2 particles is controlled by the hydrolysis process leading to rapid nucleation in the early stages of the reaction [28]. The hydrolysis reaction of TEOS is accelerated with the increase of STemp, and more favorable than poly-condensation, resulting in an increase in the number of SiO2 nuclei, suppressing growth of grains, and favoring the formation of smaller particles and agglomeration. As shown in Table 1, the surface area of the CS mixed oxide samples is observed to increase with the increase of STemp, which enhances CeO2 deposition on the surface of SiO2, causing a decrease of CeO2-a. Similarly, the crystal nucleus of CeO2 is generated rapidly at higher STemp suppressing the growth of crystal grains, resulting in a reduction of CeO2 crystallinity and formation of amorphous CeO2. It is therefore apparent that the STemp plays an important role in controlling the morphology and structure of CS mixed oxides. The morphologic structure of the CS mixed oxide has a significant influence on activity. Through comparison of CS30 and CS40 samples, we can speculate that the formation of SiO2@CeO2 with high dispersion and good crystallinity of CeO2-d is important in terms of the final catalyst activity. 3.2.4 Surface state of CS mixed oxides Fig. 12 shows the Ce 3d XPS spectrum of the CS mixed oxide samples prepared. The Ce 3d spectrum consists of two sets of spin-orbital multiplets corresponding to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 contributions, labelled as u and v, respectively [29]. The Ce 3d spectrum typically shows ten peaks, namely v0, u0, v, u, v׳, u׳, v׳׳, u׳׳, v׳׳׳, and u׳׳׳.The four peaks v0, u0, v׳, and u׳ are assigned to the Ce3+ oxidation state and the six peaks v, u, v׳׳, u׳׳, v׳׳׳, and u׳׳׳ attributed to the Ce4+ oxidation state. However it should be noted that v0 and u0 are not easy to detect in raw spectra owing to the overlap between v and u. It is therefore necessary to decompose the XPS spectra. As shown in Fig. 12, the XPS spectra obtained for the CS mixed oxides samples shows nine peaks, v0, v, u, v׳, u׳, v׳׳, u׳׳, v׳׳׳, and u׳׳׳, indicating the coexistence of both Ce4+ and Ce3+ within the CS mixed oxide samples [30,31].No obvious peak for u0 was observed, which is in agreement with prior studies [32,33]. This may be related to the small peak area of u0. (Fig. 13 ) The relative content of Ce3+ and Ce4+ oxidation states can be calculated using Eq.s (2–4) where Vχ represents the integral peak area of peak χ. (2) V C e 4 + = v + u + v ' ' + u ' ' + v ' ' ' + u ' ' ' (3) V C e 3 + = v 0 + u 0 + v ' + u ' (4) R e l a t i v e c o n t e n t o f C e 3 + = V C e 3 + ( V C e 3 + + V C e 4 + ) * 100 % The relative content of Ce3+ and Ce4+ for the CS mixed oxide samples are summarized in Table 2 . The predominance of the Ce4+ oxidation state can be clearly observed with the relative content of Ce3+ ranging from 27.2%–41.2%, and the highest Ce3+ relative content observed for the CS60 mixed oxide sample. In contrast, our previous studies have shown that the relative content of the Ce3+ oxidation state was 16.8% for pure CeO2 [20]. The high relative Ce3+ content of the CS mixed oxides compared to pure CeO2 is believed to be due to the smaller diameter of CeO2 within the CS mixed oxide material. Previous literature reports have shown that Ce3+ concentration increases with decreasing diameter of CeO2 due to the smaller nanocrystals of CeO2 possessing a higher surface to volume ratio and lower energy of reduction compared to bulk ceria [34–37]. This hypothesis is strongly supported by HRTEM results which showed that the diameters of both CeO2-a and CeO2-b within the CS mixed oxides were 2−3 nm as compared to the diameter of pure CeO2 which has been shown to be approximately 5.9 nm [20].The existence of Ce3+ could contribute towards a charge imbalance, helping to form oxygen vacancies and resulting in an increase in chemisorbed oxygen species adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Fig. 14 shows the O1s XPS spectrum of the CS mixed oxide samples. The first peak with a binding energy of between 529.88–530.58 eV was assigned to surface lattice oxygen (O2−), denoted as Oβ, and the second peak between 532.78–532.98 eV was assigned to surface absorbed oxygen species (i.e., O2 2−,O−,OH−,CO3 2−), denoted as Oα [33,38]. The proportion of the different oxygen species can be calculated using the integral peak area, and the resulting values are shown in Table 2. It was found that the relative content of Oα in the CS mixed oxide samples decreased in the following order: CS60 > CS40 > CS50 > CS30, which is consistent with the order of relative Ce3+ content with the exception of CS30. The results obtained from HRTEM showed that the CS30 sample contains a large number of CeO2-a.It indicating that CeO2-a can be considered as a form of “pure CeO2”, which does not interact with SiO2 and is present independently. According to a previous study in the literature, the oxygen storage capacity of CeO2-SiO2 mixed oxide samples are higher than that of pure CeO2 and the presence of SiO2 can promote interaction of H2 with CeO2 at much lower temperatures [39]. It can therefore be inferred that the higher relative Oαcontent of CeO2-d compared to CeO2-a is related to the formation of Si-O-Ce bonds between SiO2 and CeO2 [40] and thus the CS30 sample has higher Ce3 + and lower Oα relative content compared to the other CS mixed oxides. Usually, Oα has a higher mobility than Oβ, which is more favorable to NO oxidation to NO2 [41,42]. Therefore, Pt/CS60 shows the highest NO oxidation conversion below 200 ℃. This would imply that the Pt/CS60 would display higher NH3 oxidation activity in consideration of the highest relative content of Oα. However this was not the case with the Pt/CS60 sample showing only moderate relative activity and lower than both Pt/CS40 and Pt/CS30 samples. This suggests that the Oα content of the support is not the key factor influencing the NH3-SCO activity for Pt/CS catalyst samples. 3.2.5 Redox behavior of CS mixed oxides The H2-TPR profiles of the CS mixed oxide samples are shown in Fig. 14. The results showed that the reduction of CS mixed oxides mainly occurred in six temperature regions, and the peaks were assigned as I, II, III, IV, V, and VI corresponding to peak temperature ranges of 556.6 ℃ to 600.9 ℃, 639.6 ℃ to 678.3 ℃, 674.9 ℃ to 785.9 ℃, 796.7 ℃, 232.1 ℃, and 352 ℃ respectively. Of all the CS mixed oxide samples, only CS60 showed reduction peaks V and VI. It is speculated that peak V and VI are related to amorphous CeO2. Peak I, II, III and IV are related with the reduction of surface oxygen and lattice oxygen of CeO2. According to previous studies, the reduction temperature of lattice oxygen of CeO2-based oxides without any active metal additives is higher than 650 ℃ [38,43]. Reduction peaks III and IV have therefore been assigned to the reduction of lattice oxygen of CeO2, and reduction peaks I and II to the reduction of surface oxygen of CeO2. The redox behavior of CeO2 is closely related to the state of CeO2. According to the results obtained from HRTEM analysis, the CeO2 in the prepared samples had two states, namely CeO2-aand CeO2-d. It can therefore be inferred that peak I, II, III and IV can be assigned to either CeO2-aor CeO2-d states. Fig. 14 shows that the area of peak II decreases with increased STemp. In addition of HRTEM analysis, shows that the content of CeO2-a decreased with an increase in STemp. As such, peak II can be attributed to the surface oxygen reduction of CeO2-a, and peak I to the surface oxygen reduction of CeO2-d. A comparison of the areas of peak I and peak II in Fig. 14 suggests a higher relative amount of CeO2-d within the CS mixed oxide samples. In addition, from the HRTEM results obtained, it was observed that the amount of CeO2-a in CS40 and CS50 was very low, indicating that the content of CeO2-d was higher than CeO2-a within the samples This observation was consistent with the relative areas of peak II and peak I. Similarly, the area of peak III was observed to be significantly greater than peak IV. Therefore, peak III and IV can be attributed to the lattice oxygen reduction of CeO2-d and CeO2-a, respectively. The lack of peak IV at STemp of 40 °C and above is believed to be due to a shift in reduction temperature beyond the test temperature range The reduction temperatures of peaks I and III, attributed to CeO2-d,were lower than those of peaks II and IV, attributed to CeO2-a, indicating that CeO2 that was dispersed on the surface of SiO2 could be more easily reduced by H2. It is believed that this improved redox behavior of CeO2 is due to the formation of a shell-core structure of SiO2@CeO2. In addition, the reduction temperatures of peaks I and III are observed to shift to higher temperature with increased STemp, suggesting that that the interaction between CeO2 and SiO2 was gradually strengthened. The calculated H2 consumptions of the CS mixed oxide samples are summarized in Table 3 . The total H2 consumption of the CS mixed oxide samples was observed to decrease in the order of CS40 > CS30 > CS60 > CS50, which was consistent with the NH3 oxidation activity of the Pt/CS catalyst samples. It was also observed that the H2 consumption attributed to surface oxygen was much greater than that for lattice oxygen. The results indicate that the surface oxygen and lattice oxygen both contribute towards the NH3 oxidation reaction, but mainly surface oxygen. Table.3 also shows that the H2 consumption of the CS mixed oxide samples mainly originated from CeO2-d and that the order of H2 consumption of CeO2-d was the same as total H2 consumption for the CS mixed oxides. This indicates that the SiO2@CeO2 component is mainly responsible for the NH3-SCO activity of the Pt/CS catalyst. The H2 consumption attributed to surface oxygen for CeO2-d was observed to first decrease and then increase with increasing STemp. In combination with the results from TEM analysis, where the crystallinity of CeO2-ddecreased with the increase of STemp with the exception of the CS60 sample, it can be inferred that the crystallinity of CeO2-d and surface oxygen are related with higher crystallinity being favorable for the formation of surface oxygen. The CS60 sample showed the highest H2 consumption attributed to surface oxygen, 315.93 μmol.g−1, which may be a result of amorphous CeO2 contribution. The H2 consumption attributed to lattice oxygen for CeO2-d was observed to decrease with the crystallinity of CeO2-d with the exception of the CS40 sample which showed the highest H2 consumption attributed to lattice oxygen (135.03 μmol/g). This is believed to be due to a co-effect of high crystallinity and high dispersion. The results further indicate that the state of CeO2-d is a key factor affecting the NH3 oxidation activity of Pt/CS catalysts. 3.2.6 Acidity of CS mixed oxides The NH3-TPD profiles of the CS mixed oxide samples are shown in Fig. 15 . NH3-TPD profiles were fitted with five desorption peaks, assigned as I, II, III, IV, and V and located between temperatures of 155−170 ℃, 190−210 ℃, 240−290 ℃, 510−530 ℃ and 740−785 ℃ respectively.. According to the literature [44–46], peak I, occurring at lower temperatures of 155−170 ℃, can be attributed to the desorption of weakly adsorbed NH3., Peak II and peak III at medium temperature of 190−300 ℃, are related to the desorption of medium strong chemisorbed NH3, which can be attributed to NH3 adsorbed on support materials hydroxyl groups [47]. Peaks IV, at higher temperatures of 510−530 ℃, is attributed to be the desorption of strong chemisorbed NH3 and peaks V occurring at 740−785 ℃ is mainly associated with structural decomposition [48]. It is well known that weakly adsorbed NH3 does not chemically bond to the surface of materials, nor activate in the reaction, and that NH3 adsorption on medium-strong and strong acid sites contribute more to reactivity [41]. Therefore contributions from weakly adsorbed NH3 to the total quantitative acidity of materials have been discounted for the purposes of this discussion. Fig. 16 shows the quantitative acidity values associated with medium-strong and strong acid sites for the materials tested and was obtained by integration of the areas of peak II, peak III and peak IV. The total NH3 desorption values for the CS30, CS40, CS50, CS60 samples were 242.29 μmol/g, 453.26 μmol/g, 380.67 μmol/g and 300.69 μmol/g respectively. It can be observed that the total amounts of medium strong acid and strong acid for the CS mixed oxides prepared at different synthesis temperatures differ significantly and decrease in the order of CS40 > CS50 > CS60 > CS30. Fig. 16 shows that the medium-strong acid contribution in the CS mixed oxide samples is significantly higher than that of strong acid sites. The CS30 sample shows the highest strong acid contribution, which may be related to the CS30 sample containing the highest amount of CeO2-a. Chen and co-workers have previously shown that pure CeO2 with a spherical structure has more strong acid sites at high temperature than cube, rod and spindle structures [49]. The amount of medium-strong acid sites is observed to first increase and then decrease with increasing STemp, which may be related to the state of CeO2-d within the CS mixed oxide samples. Indeed, CeO2 doping in mixed oxides has been shown to be favorable to the formation of surface hydroxyl groups [41,50], which can be related to medium strong acid sites [47]. According to the results of HRTEM analysis, the amount of CeO2-d increases and the crystallinity of CeO2-d subsequently decreases with increasing STemp for the CS mixed oxides. This is consistent with variation in the amounts of medium-strong acid sites and indicates that CS40 has the highest medium-strong acid contribution of the samples tested due to a greater amount of CeO2-d of good crystallinity. The mechanism of the NH3-SCO reaction involves adsorption of both NH3 and O2 species, followed by the dehydrogenation of NH3 with adsorbed atomic oxygen and formation of reaction products [51–53]. As a result, the adsorption capacity for NH3 and O2 play an important role in the NH3-SCO reaction, which can be considered as one of the reasons that the CS40 material demonstrates an improved NH3 oxidation activity. 3.2.7 Oxidation activity of CS mixed oxides O2-TPD results are provided in Fig. 17 . It can be observed that six O2 desorption peak occur at temperatures of 169 ℃, 206 ℃, 262 ℃, 370 ℃, 492 ℃ and 749 ℃ respectively dependent upon the sample tested. These peaks have been labelled as peak I, II, III, IV, V and VI. Based on previous literature studies [54,55], peak I and II can be assigned to physically adsorbed O2 and weakly adsorbed surface O2 species, characteristic of van der Waals forces of attraction. Peak III, IV, V can be assigned to lattice O2 with stronger adsorption properties than those associated with Peak I and II. Peak VI is associated with internal lattice oxygen. Yao and co-workers have proposed that there are three types of O2 in CeO2, namely capping, bulk and shared [56]. Capping O2 is believed to be the most active type, and the active site of CeO2 for the reactions at temperatures below 500 ℃. The total O2 desorption of the four CS oxides samples follows the sequence of CS40 > CS30 > CS60 > CS50, which is consistent with the results of H2-TPR and confirmed that the oxygen storage capacity of the CS mixed oxide samples is very important for NH3-SCO reaction and that a high oxygen storage capacity is helpful for NH3-SCO reaction. 4 Conclusions CS mixed oxides were prepared by a sol-gel method at different STemps of 30 ℃, 40 ℃, 50 ℃, and 60 ℃. The porosity, phase, valence state, structure, morphologies, and redox behaviors of the CS mixed oxides were studied by N2 adsorption, XRD, TEM, HRTEM, XPS, NH3-TPD, O2-TPO and H2 TPR techniques. The results demonstrated that STemp had a significant impact on the physicochemical properties of the samples. CS mixed oxides with a mixture of SiO2@CeO2 and CeO2 clusters were formed at low STemp. With an increase in STemp, the number of CeO2-a gradually decreased, and the dispersion of SiO2@CeO2 and the crystallinity of CeO2-d decreased leading to the formation of aggregated SiO2@CeO2 with amorphous CeO2. Results from activity tests suggest a preferential structure of CS mixed oxides for enhancing NH3 oxidation activity of Pt/CScatalysts, namely SiO2@CeO2 with high dispersion and CeO2 crystallinity. When using the CS40 mixed oxide as a support material, the Pt/CS40 catalyst exhibited a significantly improved NH3-SCO performance compared to Pt/Al2O3 and a high NO oxidation conversion. Based on the results obtained, we can conclude that Pt/CS systems represent an alternative to traditional Pt/Al2O3 systems in the field of NH3 catalytic oxidation, and that Pt/CS40 specifically has potential application in dual-layer ASC and NO oxidation catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A series of CeO2-SiO2 (CS) mixed oxides with different textural properties were prepared by sol-gel methodology using different synthesis temperatures (STemps) in order to investigate the influence of the CS mixed oxide support on the NH3-SCO activity for Pt/CS catalysts. The results showed that the support material had a significant effect on catalytic activity. A Pt/CS catalyst, CS material synthesized at 40 °C (CS40) with a core-shell structure, high dispersion and good CeO2 crystallinity, showed excellent NH3 oxidation activity at low temperatures which was superior to the traditional Pt/Al2O3 tested. Characterization results showed that highly dispersed CeO2 on SiO2 with good CeO2 crystallinity was favorable towards the formation of surface /lattice oxygen and medium strong acid both of which were important for the NH3 oxidation reaction. This work suggests that the Pt/CS40 catalyst is a more suitable alternative to traditional lower layer Pt/Al2O3 catalyst for dual ammonia slip catalyst (ASC).
coredata.dc:title: The effect of textural properties of CeO2-SiO2 mixed oxides on NH3-SCO activity of Pt/CeO2-SiO2 catalyst
